attributes.name: ai_literacy
attributes.description: Degree of understanding of AI systems, capabilities, and limitations (0–1 scale), affecting how agents interpret and respond to ASI news.

attributes.name: tech_sector_employment
attributes.description: Whether the person works in a technology-related industry (software, AI/ML, hardware, or tech-adjacent roles), making their livelihood directly impacted by ASI.

attributes.name: knowledge_worker
attributes.description: Whether the person's job is primarily predicated on information asymmetry or cognitive output (lawyers, doctors, analysts, engineers, etc.), making them structurally redundant post-ASI.

attributes.name: personal_health_vulnerability
attributes.description: Whether the person or an immediate household member has a serious illness (cancer, Alzheimer's, ALS, diabetes, HIV) that ASI-developed cures directly address.

attributes.name: financial_market_exposure
attributes.description: Level of personal exposure to financial markets (None, Low – savings/401k only, Medium – active investments, High – significant equity/crypto/derivatives holdings), affecting economic reaction to ASI-...[truncated]

attributes.name: asi_existential_risk_belief
attributes.description: Prior belief that advanced AI poses an existential or catastrophic risk to humanity (0 = no concern, 1 = certain doom), shaping emotional and political responses to ASI arrival.

attributes.name: asi_benefit_optimism
attributes.description: Degree of optimism that ASI will produce broadly shared human benefit rather than concentrated elite capture (0–1 scale), influencing adoption and advocacy behaviors.

attributes.name: job_automation_risk_perception
attributes.description: Person's perceived likelihood that their own job or livelihood will be eliminated or severely disrupted by ASI-driven automation (0–1 scale).

attributes.name: asi_adoption_eagerness
attributes.description: Eagerness to personally adopt and integrate ASI tools into daily work and life (0–1 scale), driven by openness, literacy, and age.

attributes.name: regulatory_intervention_support
attributes.description: Strength of preference for government regulation and oversight of ASI development and deployment (0 = laissez-faire, 1 = strong state control).

attributes.name: information_network_centrality
attributes.description: Role in social information diffusion — Isolated (few connections), Peripheral (casual consumer), Connected (active sharer), Hub (opinion leader/influencer) — affecting how rapidly ASI news and attitud...[truncated]

attributes.name: economic_precarity
attributes.description: Degree of financial precarity — low savings, high debt, and dependence on wage income — that makes the agent highly sensitive to economic disruption from ASI-driven labor market changes (0–1 scale).

attributes.name: institutional_change_tolerance
attributes.description: Psychological tolerance for rapid, large-scale disruption to societal institutions, norms, and structures (0 = deeply threatened by change, 1 = fully embraces transformation).

input.notes: Big Five already exist in base population — not re-included. Focus is on attributes that create meaningful behavioral variance in an ASI-arrival scenario: how people perceive AI risk/benefit, how econ...[truncated]
